JUDGES: David Thór Björgvinsson;George Nicolaou;Ineta Ziemele;Krzysztof Wojtyczek;Päivi Hirvelä;Vincent A. De Gaetano;Zdravka Kalaydjieva
TEXT: CARDINAL . NORP The applicant , Mr PERSON , is a NORP national , who was born in DATE and lives in ORG .
CARDINAL . The NORP Government ( “ the Government ” ) were represented by their Agent , Mr J. GPE , succeeded by Ms J. Chrzanowska , of ORG .
CARDINAL . The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .
CARDINAL . The applicant is married and has CARDINAL children . Prior to his application for an EWK pension he had been employed until DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant filed an application with ORG ( ORG ) to be granted the right to an earlyretirement pension for persons raising children who , due to the seriousness of their health condition , required constant care , the so - called “ EWK ” pension .

CARDINAL . Along with his application for a pension , the applicant submitted , among other documents concerning his son ’s health , a medical certificate issued by PERSON , a urologist , which had been issued on DATE . The certificate also bore a stamp of the urology centre in GPE ( Poradnia urologiczna Przychodni Specjalistycznej CARDINAL PERSON w GPE ) ( “ the Centre ” ) and stated that the child ( born in DATE ) suffered from neurogenic bladder disorder ( dysfunkcja neurogenna pęcherza moczowego ) and was in need of the parent ’s constant care .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ( “ the FAC ” ) issued a decision granting the applicant the right to an earlyretirement pension in the net amount of MONEY ( FAC ) per month .

CARDINAL . ORG initially suspended the payment of the pension due to the fact that the applicant was still working on the date of the decision . The applicant resigned from his job where he had been working since DATE . On DATE , the payment of the pension was resumed .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG asked the ORG to provide medical documentation concerning the applicant ’s son . In reply , the FAC informed it that the child had never been registered there as a patient . However , the relevant medical documentation was provided by CARDINAL private medical establishments .
On an unknown date ORG requested ORG doctor ( PERSON ) to specify whether the applicant ’s son required the permanent care of a parent .
On DATE the doctor stated , on the basis of the medical records provided to the ORG , that the child could not be considered as ever having required such care .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG simultaneously issued CARDINAL decisions in respect of the applicant . By virtue of the first decision , the payment of the applicant ’s pension was discontinued with immediate effect . By virtue of the second decision , ORG reopened the proceedings , revoked the initial decision granting a pension and eventually refused to award the applicant the right to an early - retirement pension under the scheme provided for by the ORG ’s Ordinance of CARDINAL DATE on the right to early retirement of employees raising children who require permanent care ( ORG PERSON . DATE w sprawie uprawnień do wcześniejszej emerytury pracowników opiekujących się dziećmi wymagającymi stałej opieki ) ( “ the DATE LAW ) .

CARDINAL . The applicant appealed against these decisions . He submitted that he should receive the benefit because his child required constant care , as confirmed by the medical certificate attached to the applicant ’s original application for a pension . Moreover , the applicant alleged that the revocation of his retirement pension was contrary to the principle of vested rights .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ( Sąd ORG ) dismissed the appeal . During the proceedings , the applicant ’s son was examined by specialist urologists on CARDINAL occasions . The experts found that he suffered from a minor phimosis and nocturnal enuresis . In their view , the medical documentation did not contain any evidence that the child had ever suffered from , or had been treated for , the diseases as diagnosed by PERSON They stated that those particular disorders could not be diagnosed as such without carrying out a series of prior comprehensive examinations . The child ’s medical records did not mention any of such examinations .

ORG held that the applicant ’s child did not require his father ’s permanent care since his state of health did not significantly impair his body functions . The domestic court held that the applicant had been rightfully divested of his right to a pension under the scheme provided by the DATE Ordinance as he did not satisfy the requirement of necessary permanent care .
CARDINAL . The applicant appealed against the first - instance judgment .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ( ORG ) dismissed the appeal .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ( ORG ) refused to entertain the cassation appeal lodged by the applicant .

CARDINAL . In DATE the ORG filed a bill of indictment against ORG , a doctor from the specialist urology centre in LOC Poradnia urologiczna Przychodni Specjalistycznej CARDINAL PERSON w GPE ) ( “ FAC ) . He was charged with issuing CARDINAL fraudulent certificates confirming that CARDINAL persons ( including the applicant ’s son ) had been treated in the LOC .
CARDINAL . The applicant was questioned as a witness in the proceedings .
CARDINAL . On DATE , the doctor pleaded guilty to the charges .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG discontinued the proceedings against PERSON on the ground that the act committed was of minor significance ( “ wypadek mniejszej wagi ” ) . It further ordered him to pay a fine of PLN MONEY .

CARDINAL . Following the social security proceedings the applicant was not ordered to return his early - retirement benefits paid by ORG , despite the revocation of his right to the early - retirement pension .
CARDINAL . NORP The applicant submitted , in general , that after the revocation of the EWK pension his financial situation had been difficult .

CARDINAL . The Government submitted that the applicant owned a farm ( CARDINAL.CARDINAL hectares ) which was a source of income for him and his family . In addition , the applicant ’s wife had been employed since DATE .

CARDINAL . The legal provisions applicable at the material time and questions of practice are set out in the judgments in the case of GPE GPE , no . CARDINAL , § § ORG , DATE , and PERSON v. GPE , no . CARDINAL , § § ORG , DATE ) .
